title: Why Practicing Conversations in Your Head Actually Works
summary: How simulated dialogues can train your brain for calmer, clearer real-life interactions.
content:
When you rehearse a conversation, your brain activates many of the same networks it would use in the real interaction. 
Micro-scenarios use this effect on purpose: you mentally step into a moment, explore different reactions, and feel the emotional impact—all without the real-world risk.

That means that when a similar situation appears in your actual life, it no longer feels completely new.
You've already visited it in your mind, tested a few responses, and seen what tends to work better.

title: How to Use Micro-Scenarios as a Daily 5-Minute Habit
summary: You don't need an hour of training. Here’s how to build skill with just one scenario a day.
content:
A simple routine: pick one scenario, read it once, choose your instinctive answer, and then read the alternatives.
Notice how each choice would likely feel in your body: lighter, heavier, tense, relieved.

This kind of micro-reflection builds a mental library of responses.
Over time, you start reaching for more grounded, skillful reactions automatically.

title: Designing Safer Conversations When the Stakes Feel High
summary: Why structure, timing, and language choices matter when the topic is sensitive.
content:
High-stakes conversations feel dangerous because a lot is riding on how they go.
One way to make them safer is to design them: choose a calm time, start with impact rather than blame, and pause often to check in.

Micro-scenarios let you rehearse these design decisions ahead of time so you’re not improvising everything in the heat of the moment.
